Posts.Content: cloudynight wrote: Forgive me if this question has been asked before. If you had weekly Taxol (only) or Taxol/Herceptin (but no AC or other chemo), what happened to your hair? Did you lose it all? When? I'm getting lots of conflicting anecdotes from my doctors and nurses, so I'd love to hear about any personal experiences from the ladies here. Thanks all. Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2015 03:35PM cloudynight wrote: Yes, it is normal. I was referred to imaging by my OB/GYN after she felt a lump, and she immediately gave me the name of a few breast surgeons and advised me to make an appointment. She said, "Even if it's benign, you may need to take it out," which made sense to me.

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2015 08:29PM cloudynight wrote: Hi guys, Joining in here too. I started 12 weeks of Taxol/Herceptin on June 16. I've had crazy heartburn so far, and some annoying scalp folliculitis (likely from dexamethasone), but that's all. I did go to a scammy-feeling wig place on Thursday, where they tried to sell me a $6,500 human-hair wig. I was like, "Uh, no thanks?" I bought a $65 one from the TLC wigs site when I got home.

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2015 04:04PM cloudynight wrote: Re: B6, a friend of mine who also happens to be an MO and I have had several conversations about it. He's not convinced by the evidence for it. Don't take too much: Large doses of B6 (like 500 mg-1 g/daily) can actually cause peripheral neuropathy (although there have been cases where taking less for long periods of time have also caused it.) The recommended upper limit is 100 mg/daily. He's also not all that wild about glutamine. He told me that the best way to prevent neuropathy is to realize you're having it, tell your MO, and adjust your dose down appropriately. It's interesting that so many MOs recommend supplements. I'm on the skeptical end of the spectrum, so I'm not taking anything except for Biotin, which has improved my nails in the past.
